metadata.titleEn: 30 m land cover classification product data set of Qilian Mountain Area in 2020 (V2.0)
metadata.description: This dataset contains land cover products in Qilian Mountain Area in 2020. The dataset was produced based on the product in 2019 using change monitoring method on the Google Earth Engine platform using Landsat series data. The overall accuracy of this product is above 85%. This is a continuation of the products from 1985-2019.

background: Land-cover datasets are crucial for research on eco-hydrological processes and earth system modeling. Remote sensing has become widely used as a macro-observing system for land-cover mapping, which can substitute for plant functional type (PFT) as the baseline. Several moderate to fine resolution global land-cover datasets, which are presented in detail in Table I, based on different satellite sensors are available from different research groups. These land-cover datasets listed in Table I have large variability for three reasons: 1) the data quality and properties are different; 2) there is no standard approach for classifying continuous vegetation cover into discrete categories; and 3) they are not consistent with the Earth System Model’s (ESM) requirements, because the concept of PFT, whose traits represent a combination of spectral relationships, and climatic, ecological, and theoretical assumptions, used in ESMs cannot be mapped directly using remote-sensing land-cover datasets. In addition, the classification accuracies of land-cover datasets vary and are hardly suited for land-process modeling and applications at a river basin scale. The highest uncertainty in land-cover classification from optical remotely sensed imagery occurs most frequently between the cropland and grassland categories and in dryland systems among the shrub, grassland, and forest categories because of differences in the minimum threshold required for forest cover. For the HRB, most are distributed over an arid region, so the vegetation classification in the HRB based on current land-cover datasets would cause very large uncertainty and may cause great error or even the failure of eco-hydrological and land-process modeling.
research objective: In order to improve the accuracy of eco-hydrological and land-process modeling in the HRB, a comprehensive method for mapping monthly land cover with fine spatial resolution and more categories of crop/vegetation is developed by using multiple classifiers and multisource remotely sensed data with different spatio-temporal resolutions and spectral bands.
challenges: The highest uncertainty in land-cover classification from optical remotely sensed imagery occurs most frequently between the cropland and grassland categories and in dryland systems among the shrub, grassland, and forest categories because of differences in the minimum threshold required for forest cover. For the HRB, most are distributed over an arid region, so the vegetation classification in the HRB based on current land-cover datasets would cause very large uncertainty and may cause great error or even the failure of eco-hydrological and land-process modeling.
methods: A mosaic of the HRB is made using Landsat/TM imagery. The mosaic of Landsat/TM is used as the base image and all HJ-1/CCD images are automatically corrected through the image-to-image registration method. Converting the DN values of the HJ-1/CCD images to top of atmosphere (TOA) radiance with given calibration coefficients. Removing the atmospheric effects of remote-sensing images to obtain the surface reflectance. After the preprocessing has been done, all the HJ-1/CCD images within 1 month are subset and mosaicked; consequently, 10 mosaics for 10 months in the HRB are made and time series of the HRB mosaics from HJ-1/CCD are constructed.
dataset: The HJ-1/CCD remote-sensing data used in this research were provided by the China Centre for Resources Satellite Data and Application (CRESDA, http://www.cresda.com). The Landsat TM/ETM+ data were downloaded from the USGS website (http://landsat.usgs.gov/). The MODIS data were downloaded from the NASA Goddard Space Flight Center (http://ladsweb.nascom.nasa.gov/). The VHSR data were from Google Earth by Google Inc.
findings: The confusion matrix is used to evaluate the classification accuracy, showing an overall classification accuracy of over 90% in the HRB, which is quite higher than previous approaches. Furthermore, a ground campaign was performed to evaluate the accuracy of crop classification and an overall accuracy of 84.09% for the crop classification was achieved.

background: Long time series of land cover changes (LCCs) are critical in the analysis of long-term climate, environmental, and ecological changes. Although several moderate to fine resolution global land cover datasets have been publicly released and they show strong consistency at the global scale, they have large deviations at the regional scale; furthermore, high-quality land cover datasets from before 2000 are not available and the classification consistency among different datasets is not very good. Remote sensing has become widely used for global land cover mapping, as it can capture the changes of land cover quickly. Until now, several moderate to fine resolution global land cover datasets have been publicly released and the spatial resolutions of these products are between 1 km and 30 m. They show strong consistency at the global scale, but they have large deviations at the regional scale. The main problems include: (1) most of the land cover datasets have a relatively low resolution (500 m and lower) and their accuracies are usually lower than 75%; among the released datasets, GlobeLand30 and FROM-GLC30 have a spatial resolution of 30 m, and their overall accuracies are 80% and 72% respectively; (2) the classification accuracy of these released datasets at the regional scale is much lower than the claimed accuracy, especially at heterogeneous areas, which is difficult to meet the modeling requirements, and (3) all the datasets are after 2000 and do not have long time series and therefore cannot support the analysis of long-term climate, environmental, and ecological changes.
research objective: Therefore, by taking the advantages of the two categories of satellite data, we proposed a new time series land cover mapping method based on machine learning and it, thereafter, is applied to Heihe River Basin (HRB) for verification purposes.
challenges: Many comprehensive classification methods, such as GlobeLand30 using Landsat series satellite data have been developed but the ones with high accuracy usually require manual intervention; thus, more than 10 years’ land cover maps with areas over 140,000 km2 do not allow a lot of manual intervention. Although methods based on time series analysis like LCMM have the capability for making high-quality land cover datasets, a 16-day revisiting period of Landsat series satellite data does not support constructing time series data at HRB. Although machine learning methods, such as FROM-GLC30 have a lot of advantages and have been employed to map land cover using remote sensing imagery, they are usually limited by sampling amount and representativity; the requirement for consistency on data of these methods cannot be met by Landsat series satellite data.
methods: Firstly, the high-quality land cover datasets at HRB from 2011–2015, which were retrieved using the LCMM method, are used for quickly and accurately making training samples. Secondly, a strategy for transferring the training samples after 2011 to earlier years is established. Thirdly, the random forest model is employed to train the selected yearly samples and a land cover map for every year is subsequently made. Finally, comprehensive analysis and validation are carried out for evaluation.
dataset: Firstly, the high-quality land cover datasets at HRB from 2011–2015, which were retrieved using the LCMM method, are used for quickly and accurately making training samples.
findings: In this study, a long time series land cover dataset including 1986, 1990, 1995, 2000, 2005, 2010, 2011, 2012, 2013, 2014, and 2015 is finally made and an average precision of about 90% is achieved. It is the longest time series land cover map with 30 m resolution at HRB and the dataset has good time continuity and stability.

background: It is very difficult to have remote sensing data with both high spatial resolution and high temporal frequency; thus, two categories of land-use mapping methodology have been developed separately for coarser resolution and finer resolution data. Land use and land cover are the key factors for understanding the interactions between global changes and human activities, such as social, economic, and cultural activities. Moreover, it is one of the key parameters of land process modeling, and more accurate land use and land cover data will improve the accuracy of ecological, hydrological, and atmospheric models. Consequently, land use and land cover data are now widely used in many kinds of researches, such as biodiversity, carbon cycle, public health, crop yield estimation, urban sprawl, forest monitoring, and so on. Since land cover/use can be retrieved straightforwardly from remote sensing, many land cover/use mapping methods using remotely sensed data have been developed for the purposes of regional or global applications.
research objective: Therefore, by taking the spatiotemporal advantage of HJ-1/CCD data we propose a new method for finer resolution land cover mapping using the time series HJ-1/CCD data, which can greatly improve the land cover mapping accuracy.
challenges: This method uses much more data and dramatically increases the computation loading; the not very good geometric and radiometric qualities of HJ-1/CCD data lower its usability and increase the difficulty in its use.
methods: In our two study areas, the very high resolution remote sensing data within Google Earth are used to validate the land cover mapping results, which shows a very high mapping accuracy of 95.76% and 83.78% and a high Kappa coefficient of 0.9423 and 0.8165 in the Dahuofang area of Liaoning Province and the Heiquan area of Gansu Province respectively.
dataset: The HJ-1 satellite constellation consists of three satellites, named as HJ-1A, HJ-1B, and HJ-1C respectively. For CCD cameras, their nominal spatial resolution is 30 m. HJ-1/CCDs have three visible bands (430–520 nm, 520–600 nm, and 630–690 nm) and one near-infrared band (760–900 nm). The time series data are composed of one dataset per month, so this time series of data can depict the variation of typical land surface.
findings: The overall accuracy for classification result using the time series of HJ-1/CCD data is 96.76% and the Kappa coefficient is 0.9423; the corresponding overall accuracy and Kappa coefficient for classification result using single Hj-1/CCD data are 87.59% and 0.8296 respectively. Compared with the classification result from single Hj-1/CCD data, the overall accuracy of classification result using the time series HJ-1/CCD data is more than 10% and the Kappa coefficient is more than 0.1. The overall accuracy and Kappa coefficient of classification result using the time series HJ-1/CCD data are 83.78% and 0.8165 respectively; those using single HJ-1/CCD data are 70.82% and 0.665 respectively. It is similar to the comparison in the Dahuofang area that the overall accuracy of classification result using the time series HJ-1/CCD data is also 10% higher and Kappa coefficient is also 0.1 higher than that of classification result using single HJ-1/CCD data.

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method that improves the accuracy of land cover mapping with fine spatial resolution?
Example.Answer: One example is the use of multiple classifiers and multisource remotely sensed data with different spatio-temporal resolutions and spectral bands, as described in the research objective for improving eco-hydrological and land-process modeling accuracy in the HRB.

Example.Question: Can you give an example of a specific dataset that was used to construct a time series of land cover data?
Example.Answer: The HJ-1/CCD remote-sensing data, which includes monthly datasets, was used to construct a time series of land cover data in the Heihe River Basin, providing an overall classification accuracy of 96.76%.

Example.Question: Could you provide an example of a challenge faced in land cover classification using remote sensing imagery?
Example.Answer: An example of a challenge is the high uncertainty in classifying land cover categories such as cropland and grassland using optical remotely sensed imagery, especially in arid regions like HRB, due to differences in the minimum threshold required for forest cover.

Feature Specification.Answer: high uncertainty in distinguishing between cropland and grassland, high uncertainty among shrub, grassland, and forest categories in dryland systems, differences in the minimum threshold required for forest cover, inherent variability in land-cover datasets, potential errors in eco-hydrological and land-process modeling in arid regions

Definition.Question: What are the main challenges associated with land-cover classification using optical remote sensing imagery?
Definition.Answer: The main challenges in land-cover classification using optical remote sensing imagery include high uncertainty in distinguishing between similar land categories such as cropland and grassland, especially in arid and dryland systems. This is often due to differences in the minimum threshold needed for forest cover, which can lead to significant errors in eco-hydrological and land-process modeling. Additionally, data quality, classification accuracy, and the lack of standard approaches for discrete category classification contribute to these challenges.

Definition.Question: What are the methods used to improve the accuracy of long-term land-cover datasets for regional analysis?
Definition.Answer: To improve the accuracy of long-term land-cover datasets for regional analysis, methods such as the use of machine learning models like random forest are employed. These methods leverage high-quality datasets to create training samples, which are then used to develop comprehensive time series land-cover maps. Techniques like the LCMM method for sample transfer across years and the use of multisource satellite data help construct consistent and precise datasets, achieving high classification accuracy for regional applications.

Comparison.Question: In what ways do the HJ-1/CCD data's spatiotemporal advantages enhance land cover mapping accuracy compared to using Landsat series satellite data alone?
Comparison.Answer: HJ-1/CCD data provide a finer resolution and higher temporal frequency, which enhances land cover mapping accuracy significantly. The overall accuracy of classification results using time series HJ-1/CCD data is 96.76%, which is more than 10% higher than results using single HJ-1/CCD data, and 10% higher in comparison to using Landsat data alone, which is limited by its 16-day revisiting period.

Interpretation.Question: What are the potential implications of using multiple classifiers and multisource remotely sensed data for improving land cover mapping accuracy in eco-hydrological and land-process modeling?
Interpretation.Answer: Using multiple classifiers and multisource remotely sensed data can potentially enhance mapping accuracy by leveraging different spatio-temporal resolutions and spectral bands, which may address classification uncertainties between similar land covers like cropland and grassland. This comprehensive approach could lead to more accurate eco-hydrological and land-process modeling, particularly in heterogeneous or arid regions.

Interpretation.Question: How might the integration of high-quality land cover datasets from multiple years be utilized to improve the training samples for machine learning models in land cover mapping?
Interpretation.Answer: Integrating high-quality land cover datasets from multiple years can enhance the training sample quality for machine learning models by providing a robust baseline for transferring training samples across different time periods. This strategy can help in developing consistent and accurate land cover maps over time, which is crucial for analyzing long-term environmental and ecological changes.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the variability in land-cover dataset classification accuracies when using remote sensing imagery?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The classification accuracies of land-cover datasets vary due to differences in data quality and properties, the lack of a standard approach for classifying continuous vegetation cover into discrete categories, and inconsistencies with Earth System Model requirements. Additionally, high uncertainty occurs in differentiating categories like cropland and grassland, especially in arid regions.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes the increase in computation loading when utilizing finer resolution land cover mapping techniques?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The use of much more data in finer resolution land cover mapping techniques dramatically increases computation loading. Moreover, the not very good geometric and radiometric qualities of certain remote sensing data, such as HJ-1/CCD, lower its usability and increase the difficulty in processing, adding to the computational demands.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential consequences on land cover classification accuracy when using multiple classifiers and multisource remotely sensed data with different spatio-temporal resolutions and spectral bands?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Using multiple classifiers and multisource remotely sensed data with different spatio-temporal resolutions and spectral bands can significantly improve land cover classification accuracy. As evidenced in the research content, this approach led to an overall classification accuracy of over 90% in the Heihe River Basin (HRB), which is higher than previous approaches.

Causal Consequence.Question: How does the use of long time series of land cover datasets impact the analysis of long-term climate, environmental, and ecological changes?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Long time series of land cover datasets allow for a comprehensive analysis of long-term climate, environmental, and ecological changes. Such datasets provide strong consistency at a global scale and support the analysis by offering insights into changes across various time periods, although challenges exist in achieving high classification consistency and accuracy at regional scales.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the effects of utilizing time series HJ-1/CCD data on the accuracy of land cover mapping?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Utilizing time series HJ-1/CCD data can greatly improve the accuracy of land cover mapping. The findings indicate that the overall classification accuracy and Kappa coefficient are significantly higher when using time series data compared to single HJ-1/CCD data, with improvements of over 10% in accuracy and 0.1 in Kappa coefficient.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it essential to develop a comprehensive method for mapping monthly land cover with fine spatial resolution in eco-hydrological and land-process modeling?
Goal Orientation.Answer: In order to improve the accuracy of eco-hydrological and land-process modeling, particularly in regions like the Heihe River Basin (HRB), a comprehensive method for mapping monthly land cover with fine spatial resolution is necessary. This is due to the high uncertainty in land-cover classification, which can lead to significant errors or failures in modeling these processes.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the significance of using HJ-1/CCD data for finer resolution land cover mapping?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Using HJ-1/CCD data is significant for finer resolution land cover mapping as it can greatly improve mapping accuracy due to its spatiotemporal advantages. This leads to a higher overall classification accuracy and Kappa coefficient, enhancing the reliability of land cover datasets for various applications.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedures are followed to preprocess remote-sensing images for land cover classification, and how do these steps contribute to the accuracy of the classification?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The preprocessing of remote-sensing images involves several steps such as using a mosaic of Landsat/TM imagery as the base image, automatic correction of all HJ-1/CCD images through image-to-image registration, converting DN values to top of atmosphere radiance with given calibration coefficients, and removing atmospheric effects to obtain surface reflectance. These steps ensure that the images are synchronized and corrected for accurate classification, contributing significantly to the accuracy of the land cover classification.

Enablement.Question: What technological advancements enable the collection and processing of high-resolution land cover data for eco-hydrological modeling?
Enablement.Answer: Remote sensing advancements, particularly through platforms like Google Earth Engine and satellites such as Landsat and HJ-1/CCD, facilitate high-resolution land cover data collection. These technologies leverage spectral bands and spatio-temporal resolutions to improve data accuracy, crucial for eco-hydrological modeling.

Enablement.Question: In what ways can time series data from satellite constellations support long-term land cover change analysis?
Enablement.Answer: Time series data from satellite constellations like HJ-1/CCD enable continuous monitoring of land cover changes over extended periods. These datasets provide valuable insights into climate, environmental, and ecological changes, supporting long-term analysis with improved temporal resolution.

Expectation.Question: Why might land-cover datasets exhibit significant variability at the regional scale even when they show consistency at the global scale?
Expectation.Answer: Land-cover datasets may exhibit significant variability at the regional scale due to differences in data quality and properties, lack of a standard approach for classifying continuous vegetation cover into discrete categories, and inconsistencies with Earth System Model requirements. Additionally, regional deviations are more pronounced in heterogeneous areas, which can impact the classification accuracy required for modeling.

Expectation.Question: What challenges might arise when using time series analysis for creating high-quality land cover datasets?
Expectation.Answer: Challenges in using time series analysis for high-quality land cover datasets include the need for high-resolution data, which typically comes at a lower temporal frequency, and the manual intervention often required for high accuracy classification methods. Additionally, the revisiting period of available satellite data, such as the 16-day period for Landsat series, may not support comprehensive time series data construction.

Expectation.Question: Why might there be high uncertainty in land-cover classification from optical remotely sensed imagery, especially in certain vegetation categories?
Expectation.Answer: High uncertainty in land-cover classification from optical remotely sensed imagery often occurs between cropland and grassland categories, and among shrub, grassland, and forest categories in dryland systems. This uncertainty arises due to differences in the minimum threshold required for forest cover and the challenges in distinguishing these categories based on spectral data alone.

Judgmental.Question: How do you evaluate the effectiveness of using multiple classifiers and multisource remotely sensed data for improving land cover mapping accuracy?
Judgmental.Answer: Using multiple classifiers and multisource remotely sensed data appears to be effective in improving land cover mapping accuracy, as it leverages different spatio-temporal resolutions and spectral bands, leading to an overall classification accuracy of over 90% in certain regions. This approach addresses the high uncertainty often found in land-cover classifications, particularly in arid regions.

Judgmental.Question: What do you think is the potential impact of geometric and radiometric quality issues in time series data on land cover mapping, and how can these issues be mitigated?
Judgmental.Answer: Geometric and radiometric quality issues can significantly lower the usability of time series data and increase the difficulty of its use. Mitigation strategies include preprocessing steps such as image-to-image registration and atmospheric correction, which are essential to improve the surface reflectance data quality, thus enhancing mapping accuracy.

Assertion.Question: I'm unsure about how remote sensing data can be effectively utilized for accurate land cover mapping in eco-hydrological modeling.
Assertion.Answer: Remote sensing is widely used as it provides a macro-observing system for land-cover mapping, which can substitute for plant functional type (PFT) as a baseline. Challenges include classification accuracy, particularly between cropland and grassland or in dryland systems. Various methods, such as using multiple classifiers and multisource data, are employed to improve accuracy.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand how machine learning methods can overcome the inconsistencies in data quality for land cover classification.
Assertion.Answer: Machine learning methods, like the random forest model, are used to train selected samples for land cover mapping. Despite limitations in sampling and data consistency, these methods benefit from high-quality datasets and strategies such as transferring training samples to improve classification accuracy and stability.

Assertion.Question: I can't make sense of why high spatial resolution data have limitations in temporal frequency for land-cover mapping.
Assertion.Answer: High spatial resolution data often come with challenges in temporal frequency due to the revisit period of satellites. Two separate methodologies have been developed for different resolutions, but combining high spatial and temporal resolution remains difficult. The use of time series data, like HJ-1/CCD, aims to overcome these limitations by providing monthly datasets.

Request/Directive.Question: Please summarize the methods used for land cover mapping using remote sensing data and discuss the advantages and disadvantages of these methods.
Request/Directive.Answer: Land cover mapping using remote sensing data often involves using multiple classifiers and multisource data with varying spatio-temporal resolutions and spectral bands. Advantages include the capability to produce high-resolution and accurate land cover maps, such as those achieved with mosaic techniques using Landsat/TM and HJ-1/CCD imagery. However, challenges include high computation loading and issues with the geometric and radiometric quality of data. Machine learning methods like random forests are also employed to overcome limitations of sampling representativity and to ensure consistency across different data sources.

Request/Directive.Question: Please analyze the main challenges in achieving high classification accuracy in land cover datasets and propose potential strategies to overcome these challenges.
Request/Directive.Answer: Main challenges in achieving high classification accuracy include variability in data quality, lack of standard classification approaches, and deviations at regional scales. In particular, uncertainty arises in distinguishing between categories like cropland and grassland or among shrub, grassland, and forest in dryland systems. Strategies to overcome these challenges involve using high-quality datasets for training, employing machine learning models for improved consistency, and leveraging time series data for better temporal resolution. Additionally, methods like image registration and atmospheric correction are essential preprocessing steps to enhance data quality.
